block.p: House and Senate Panels Endorse China Trade Bill Congress took its first steps toward approving a trade bill designed to change the United States' relationship with China, as a House and a Senate committee each resoundingly endorsed the measure in important test votes.

Half a dozen previously uncommitted House Republicans and Democrats said they would support the legislation granting China permanent normal trading privileges. Administration officials and congressional backers say they now think they are close to having collected the 218 votes needed for passage in the House, but they are still locked in a battle to put the measure over the top. [Page A1.]

A.I.G. Head to Reconsider Board Fending off questions from shareholders at the annual meeting of the American International Group, Maurice R. Greenberg, its chief executive, said he would consider reversing the insider dominance of his board. But he would not budge on his designation of his son, Evan, as his eventual successor. Shares of the company fell $4.5625, to $118.125. [C6.]

Campbell Soup Profit Drops 14% With sales of its soups on the wane, Campbell Soup said that its third-quarter earnings fell 14 percent and warned that the rest of its fiscal year was unlikely to be much better. [C8.]

Stocks Fall on Fed's Rate Warning Stocks fell as investors took some profits and re-examined the potential effect of higher interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 164.83 points, or 1.5 percent, to 10,769.74. The Nasdaq composite index shed 72.61 points, or 1.95 percent, to 3,644.96, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 18.24 points, or 1.2 percent, to 1,447.80. [C11.]

Ford to Produce Fewer Excursions Ford said that it would produce fewer Excursion sport utility vehicles during the 2001 model year, but attributed the cutback to weak consumer demand rather than concerns about its safety and environmental problems. [C9.]

Toyota Posts 25% Gain in Earnings Toyota Motor posted a 25 percent gain in profit for the second half of its fiscal year, helped by robust sales in North America and Japan and cost-cutting that partly offset the effects of a strong yen on profits made overseas. [C4.]

Editor Steps Down at Real Simple In a management shake-up that shows that even the most promising publishing team does not always guarantee a smooth start-up, the managing editor of Real Simple -- a new magazine from Time for women who want to simplify their lives -- resigned. The departure of the editor, Susan Wyland, comes after only two issues of the magazine, both of which have been criticized by some advertisers as overly spare and unwelcoming. [C10.]

Rescue of ICO Global Is Completed Craig O. McCaw announced the completion of his investment group's $1.2 billion rescue of ICO Global Communications, which went bankrupt developing a satellite telecommunications network. And he intends to merge the company with Teledesic. [C8.]

Sale of Bank Is Opposed in Brazil Brazil has reduced state ownership of telecommunications, power and mining companies in what is regarded as a highly successful privatization. But the government is facing unexpectedly tough resistance to selling one of the biggest state assets, the bank Banespa. [C4.]
Vodafone to Sell Stake in Cegetel Vodafone AirTouch, the wireless telephone operator, will sell its 15 percent stake in the French telecommunications operator Cegetel to Vivendi of France. [C4.]

Elephants and Economic Theories While many people tend to see Africa as a mythic place, Africans face the same issues of scarcity and incentives that affect everyone else. And one of the hottest issues is what to do about ivory and the preservation of elephants. Virginia Postrel: Economic Scene. [C2.]
